ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Not much at all. Some of the curator visits were cool.
I learned all about color and how to analyze art pieces in person. I also learned how to search and request for objects.
In this course, I learned how to better understand art and the history behind various types of color (whether dye, paint, etc).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Some of the curator visits were cool.
Weakness: The instructors had a very strict grading system for all assignments and an even stricter grading system that was very biased towards their likes for presentations and discussions. I was consistently penalized for trying to make jokes or encourage informal discussions that somewhat related to the topics during presentations or discussions. I was penalized on a major presentation assignment because the text on my slides was "not scholarly enough." I was also penalized for going over time for my presentation when as soon as my presentation ended, the class ended with 15 minutes to spare... A lot of the invited curators struggle to find things to talk about related to "color" in which they waffle about their objects for a long time. Color is not only emphasized in the course but often it is the only topic that you are allowed to converse about with the instructors shutting down all other conversations even adjacently related to how form impacts the color of a painting/object.

Strengths are we got to go to museums and do a range of activities. Weaknesses were sometimes the visits weren't very engaging or interactive. The canvas page was also pretty confusing with assignments and readings.

Strengths: learn about art history, visit special collections and libraries, and get access to certain resources as a first year
Weaknesses: may be a bit different from what you wanted out of an "art" course, there's less hands-on activities than expected and it's mostly based on readings and discussions for learning

The biggest strength of this course is its visits to special collections, all of which are really interesting. I wish that the course overall had a bit more cohesion, though, as I felt we jumped around a bit in regards to color (this is probably just because there are so many topics and hard to make them all entirely relate). I also found grading/feedback a bit harsh in the beginning, though eventually got the hang of it (which I think has also made me a better writer and observer).

Library trips and hands-on experimented is nice

Very picky in grading reflection posts and they worth very little

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
No, I would not recommend this course to another student.
This course was okay during the curator visits (they were pretty cool). 
However, the grading of this course and how the instructors enforce their idea of what this course should be limits productive discussions and conversations.
There was only one track of possible conversation, and everything had to revolve around color. This law was enforced with an iron fist by the instructors. If you do not want to talk about color ONLY, look elsewhere for a class.
This class's workload was crazy with the time you have to cater (and guess) towards what the instructors wanted on their assignments (believe me, they will penalize you).
Also, the final assignment is either a 10-page research paper pretty much ONLY about color or a creative project with a 5-page reflective essay about color.
I would if they were interested in art but I could see how someone not interested in art wouldn't find it interesting.

Yes simply because of the familiarity you get with the special collections. You get to see so many beautiful pieces, and also feel comfortable visiting special collections on their own. Great course for that alone (though all the material is also super interesting).
Yes, good intro course to art history
